channel.title: Java Help
channel.description:
So im makign a guessing game were u type in a number 1-10 and you either win or loose. Now how do I make it so the answer is randomly 1-10. Not just 1 specific integer. For example, the answer is chosen here:
[code=java] if (sPassword.equals("1")) { [/code]
1 is the answer. How do i make it randomly choose 1-10 each time they play. this way it isnt 1 forever. thanks

item.title: Java Help
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“Dunder Mifflin, post:9, topic:437479”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=540187.msg3955519#msg3955519 date=1332712117]
Best way in my opinion… Takes out the requirement of recalling

int guess = Integer.parseInt(sPassword);
if (guess == (int)((Math.random() * 10) + 1)) {
     System.out.println("Correct! The number was indeed "+guess+".");
} else {
     System.out.println("Wrong, sorry. The number was not " +guess+". There is a new number.");
}

[/quote]

already done but thanks. Also, do you kow how to type/put things In a jframe. i only know how to put shit on .bat windows like System.out.println(“hey”);[/quote]

import javax.swing.JButton;
import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.JLabel;
import javax.swing.SwingUtilities;

public class BasicGui implements Runnable {
public void run() {
public JFrame f = new JFrame("Basic GUI"); //JFrame initialization
public JLabel text = new JLabel("Random text"); //JButton initialization
f.getContentPane().add(text);
f.pack();
f.setVisible(true);
}
public void main(String args[]){
BasicGUI one = new BasicGUI();
SwingUtilities.invokeLater(one);
}
}

Later, use:

text.setText("New text here, yeah?");

Please excuse the awful conventions, typed it up in the quick reply box.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Help
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Best way in my opinion… Takes out the requirement of recalling

int guess = Integer.parseInt(sPassword);
if (guess == (int)((Math.random() * 10) + 1)) {
     System.out.println("Correct! The number was indeed "+guess+".");
} else {
     System.out.println("Wrong, sorry. The number was not " +guess+". There is a new number.");
}

item.title: Java Help
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

[code=java5]//Game Created By Anthony
import java.util.Scanner;
public class UserGame {

public static void main(String [] args) {

	Player p1 = new Player();
	Player p2 = new Player();
	Player p3 = new Player();
	
	int theNumber;
	boolean guessedTheNumber = false;
	Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);
	
	System.out.println("WELCOME TO THE NUMBER GUESSING GAME.");
	System.out.println("YOU HAVE A 10% CHANCE OF WINNING EACH TIME!.");
	
	while (guessedTheNumber == false) {

		theNumber = (int) (Math.random() * 10) + 1;
	
		System.out.println("Enter your guess of a number 1-10: ");
		String sPassword = scan.nextLine();
	
		if (Integer.parseInt(sPassword) == theNumber) {
	
			System.out.println("The number you guessed was correct!");
	
		
		} else {
		
			System.out.println("You didnt guess the number correctly! Try again!");
	
		}

	}

}

}[/code]

I fixed it so that the number generated is actually 1 - 10 and changed the if statement. You were just checking to see if what the player typed in was 1 not if what they typed in was the same number so I changed it to

Hope that helped!
